A descendant of Benjamin; one of the tribe of Benjamin.
The common yellow-flowered avens of Europe (Geum urbanum); herb bennet. The name is sometimes given to other plants, as the hemlock, valerian, etc.
imp. & p. p. of Bend.
Changed by pressure so as to be no longer straight; crooked; as, a bent pin; a bent lever.

Strongly inclined toward something, so as to be resolved, determined, set, etc.; -- said of the mind, character, disposition, desires, etc., and used with on; as, to be bent on going to college; he is bent on mischief.
A declivity or slope, as of a hill.
A grass of the genus Agrostis, esp. Agrostis vulgaris, or redtop. The name is also used of many other grasses, esp. in America.
Relating to the deepest zone or region of the ocean.
Of or pertaining to Bentham or Benthamism.

That phase of the doctrine of utilitarianism taught by Jeremy Bentham; the doctrine that the morality of actions is estimated and determined by their utility; also, the theory that the sensibility to pleasure and the recoil from pain are the only motives which influence human desires and actions, and that these are the sufficient explanation of ethical and jural conceptions.
One who believes in Benthamism.
The season when pigeons are said to feed on bents, before peas are ripe.
Act of benumbing, or state of being benumbed; torpor.
A transparent crystalline substance, C6H5.CO.NH2, obtained by the action of ammonia upon chloride of benzoyl, as also by several other reactions with benzoyl compounds.

A volatile, very inflammable liquid, C6H6, contained in the naphtha produced by the destructive distillation of coal, from which it is separated by fractional distillation. The name is sometimes applied also to the impure commercial product or benzole, and also, but rarely, to a similar mixed product of petroleum.

A liquid consisting mainly of the lighter and more volatile hydrocarbons of petroleum or kerosene oil, used as a solvent and for cleansing soiled fabrics; -- called also petroleum spirit, petroleum benzine. Varieties or similar products are gasoline, naphtha, rhigolene, ligroin, etc.
A white crystalline substance, C14H12O2, obtained from benzoic aldehyde and some other sources.
An impure benzene, used in the arts as a solvent, and for various other purposes. See Benzene.
A compound radical, C6H5.CH2, related to toluene and benzoic acid; -- commonly used adjectively.
To paint; to cover or color with, or as with, paint.
To pinch, or mark with pinches.
To pommel; to beat, as with a stick; figuratively, to assail or criticise in conversation, or in writing.
To praise greatly or extravagantly.
To give or leave by will; to give by testament; -- said especially of personal property.
To hand down; to transmit.
The act of bequeathing; bequeathment; bequest.
The act of bequeathing or leaving by will; as, a bequest of property by A. to B.
That which is left by will, esp. personal property; a legacy; also, a gift.
To rain upon; to wet with rain.
To make rattle; to scold vociferously; to cry down.
TO make foul; to soil; to defile.

A member of a race somewhat resembling the Arabs, but often classed as Hamitic, who were formerly the inhabitants of the whole of North Africa from the Mediterranean southward into the Sahara, and who still occupy a large part of that region; -- called also Kabyles. Also, the language spoken by this people.
An alkaloid obtained, as a bitter, yellow substance, from the root of the barberry, gold thread, and other plants.
,n.A kind of neckcloth.
To make destitute; to deprive; to strip; -- with of before the person or thing taken away.
A large mass or hill, as of ice.
The essence or perfume made from the fruit.

(Min.) An earthy substance, resembling fine flour. It is composed of the shells of infusoria, and in Lapland and Sweden is sometimes eaten, mixed with flour or ground birch bark, in times of scarcity. This name is also given to a white powdery variety of calcite.
A rustic dance, so called in ridicule of the people of Bergamo, in Italy, once noted for their clownishness.
The Norway haddock. See Rosefish.
To mention in rhyme or verse; to rhyme about.
An acute disease occurring in India, characterized by multiple inflammatory changes in the nerves, producing great muscular debility, a painful rigidity of the limbs, and cachexy.
,a.Of or relating to Bishop Berkeley or his system of idealism; as, Berkeleian philosophy.
A four-wheeled carriage, having a sheltered seat behind the body and separate from it, invented in the 17th century, at Berlin.
Fine worsted for fancy-work; zephyr worsted; -- called also Berlin wool.
A ledge at the bottom of a bank or cutting, to catch earth that may roll down the slope, or to strengthen the bank.
A Brazilian dipterous insect of the genus Trypeta, which lays its eggs in the nostrils or in wounds of man and beast, where the larv\'91 do great injury.
Of or pertaining to St. Bernard of Clairvaux, or to the Cistercian monks.
Pertaining to the city o<?/ canton of Bern, in Switzerland, or to its inhabitants.
To rob; to plunder.
A small, oval, transparent jellyfish, belonging to the Ctenophora.
A square cap worn by ecclesiastics of the Roman Catholic Church. A cardinal's berretta is scarlet; that worn by other clerics is black, except that a bishop's is lined with green.
Furnished with berries; consisting of a berry; baccate; as, a berried shrub.
Any small fleshy fruit, as the strawberry, mulberry, huckleberry, etc.
A mound; a hillock.
One of a class of legendary heroes, who fought frenzied by intoxicating liquors, and naked, regardless of wounds.
One who fights as if frenzied, like a Berserker.
To allot or furnish berths to, on shipboard; as, to berth a ship's company.
A place for mooring vessels in a dock or harbor.
A double sulphide of antimony and iron, of a dark steel-gray color.
The planking outside of a vessel, above the sheer strake.

A mineral of great hardness, and, when transparent, of much beauty. It occurs in hexagonal prisms, commonly of a green or bluish green color, but also yellow, pink, and white. It is a silicate of aluminium and glucinum (beryllium). The aquamarine is a transparent, sea-green variety used as a gem. The emerald is another variety highly prized in jewelry, and distinguished by its deep color, which is probably due to the presence of a little oxide of chromium.
Like a beryl; of a light or bluish green color.
A metallic element found in the beryl. See Glucinum.
A solid consisting of a double twelve-sided pyramid; -- so called because the planes of this form occur on crystals of beryl.
A kind of writ which formerly lay where a great-grandfather died seized of lands in fee simple, and on the day of his death a stranger abated or entered and kept the heir out. This is now abolished.
To cover sparsely by scattering (something); to strew.
To cover with scrawls; to scribble over.
Entreating urgently; imploring; as, a beseeching look.
The act of beseeching or entreating earnestly.
Habitually attacking, harassing, or pressing upon or about; as, a besetting sin.
To shine upon; to ullumine.
A large food fish (Anoplopoma fimbria) of the north Pacific coast; -- called also candlefish.
To curse; to execrate.
To shut up or out.
At the side of; on one side of.
Aside from; out of the regular course or order of; in a state of deviation from; out of.
More than that; over and above; not included in the number, or in what has been mentioned; moreover; in addition.
That besieges; laying siege to.
To suit; to fit; to become.
To daub with slime; to soil.
To smear with any viscous, glutinous matter; to bedaub; to soil.
To smirch or soil; to discolor; to obscure. Hence: To dishonor; to sully.
To harden or dry in smoke.
To scatter like snow; to cover thick, as with snow flakes.
To cover with snow; to whiten with snow, or as with snow.
A brush of twigs for sweeping; a broom; anything which sweeps away or destroys.
To assort or be congruous with; to fit, or become.
To adorn with spangles; to dot or sprinkle with something brilliant or glittering.
To asperse with calumny or reproach.
To show beforehand; to foretell; to indicate.
To mark with speckles or spots.
To season with spice, or with some spicy drug.
To mark with spots, or as with spots.
To spread or cover over.
The act of sprinkling anything; a sprinkling over.
To spurt on or over; to asperse.
Having good qualities in the highest degree; most good, kind, desirable, suitable, etc.; most excellent; as, the best man; the best road; the best cloth; the best abilities.
Beset; put in peril.
To sprinkle with, or as with, stars; to decorate with, or as with, stars; to bestud.
Having the qualities of a beast; brutal; below the dignity of reason or humanity; irrational; carnal; beastly; sensual.
The state or quality of being bestial.
Unnatural connection with a beast.
To stick over, as with sharp points pressed in; to mark by infixing points or spots here and there; to pierce.
To put into brisk or vigorous action; to move with life and vigor; -- usually with the reciprocal pronoun.
The act of giving or bestowing; a conferring or bestowal.
That which is given or bestowed.
Out of one's senses; distracted; mad.
To strew or scatter over; to besprinkle.
p. p. of Bestrew.
imp. & p. p. Bestick.
To set or adorn, as with studs or bosses; to set thickly; to stud; as, to bestud with stars.
An early form of Better.
To have recourse to; to apply; to resort; to go; -- with a reflexive pronoun.
To better; to mend. See Beete.
To give ; to bestow; to grant; to accord; to consent.
To allow; to permit; to suffer.
A bright star of the first magnitude, near one shoulder of Orion.
The nutlike seed of the areca palm, chewed in the East with betel leaves (whence its name) and shell lime.
Something especially hated or dreaded; a bugbear.
A highly elastic wood, used for fishing rods, etc. The tree is unknown, but it is thought to be East Indian.
A place of worship; a hallowed spot.
In the Ethiopic church, a small building attached to a church edifice, in which the bread for the eucharist is made.
An insane person; a madman; a bedlamite.
To reduce to thralldom; to inthrall.
To attack with the tongue; to abuse; to insult.
A plant of the genus Betonica (Linn.).
Torn in pieces; tattered.
To put in violent motion; to agitate; to disturb; to toss.
To put trappings on; to clothe; to deck.
To prove faithless or treacherous to, as to a trust or one who trusts; to be false to; to deceive; as, to betray a person or a cause.
One who, or that which, betrays.
To trust or intrust.
The act of intrusting, or the thing intrusted.
Having good qualities in a greater degree than another; as, a better man; a better physician; a better house; a better air.
One who has a claim to precedence; a superior, as in merit, social standing, etc.; -- usually in the plural.
More correctly or thoroughly.
A making better; amendment; improvement.
An improvement of an estate which renders it better than mere repairing would do; -- generally used in the plural.
The difference by which fine gold or silver exceeds in fineness the standard.
One who bets; a better.
A name of contempt given to a man who interferes with the duties of women in a household, or who occupies himself with womanish matters.
Used in expressing motion from one body or place to another; from one to another of two.
In the space which separates; between.

Any angle other than a right angle; the angle which one surface makes with another when they are not at right angles; the slant or inclination of such surface; as, to give a bevel to the edge of a table or a stone slab; the bevel of a piece of timber.

An instrument consisting of two rules or arms, jointed together at one end, and opening to any angle, for adjusting the surfaces of work to the same or a given inclination; -- called also a bevel square.
Hence: Morally distorted; not upright.
To deviate or incline from an angle of 90<?/, as a surface; to slant.
The replacement of an edge by two similar planes, equally inclined to the including faces or adjacent planes.
A light repast between meals; a lunch.
Liquid for drinking; drink; -- usually applied to drink artificially prepared and of an agreeable flavor; as, an intoxicating beverage.
Specifically, a name applied to various kinds of drink.
A company; an assembly or collection of persons, especially of ladies.
A flock of birds, especially quails or larks; also, a herd of roes.
One who bewails or laments.
The act of bewailing.
To keep watch over; to keep awake.
To pronounce or characterize as a whore.
The state of being bewildered; bewilderment.
Causing bewilderment or great perplexity; as, bewildering difficulties.
The state of being bewildered.
A bewildering tangle or confusion.
A double slip of leather by which bells are fastened to a hawk's legs.
To gain an ascendency over by charms or incantations; to affect (esp. to injure) by witchcraft or sorcery.
The power of bewitching or fascinating; bewitchment; charm; fascination.
The act of bewitching, or the state of being bewitched.
The power of bewitching or charming.
To wonder at; to admire.
To expose; to reveal; to disclose; to betray.
To wreak; to avenge.
The territory ruled by a bey.
On the further side of; in the same direction as, and further on or away than.
At a place or time not yet reached; before.
A circle in or, i. e., gold, representing the gold coin called bezant.
The rim which encompasses and fastens a jewel or other object, as the crystal of a watch, in the cavity in which it is set.
A game at cards in which various combinations of cards in the hand, when declared, score points.

A calculous concretion found in the intestines of certain ruminant animals (as the wild goat, the gazelle, and the Peruvian llama) formerly regarded as an unfailing antidote for poison, and a certain remedy for eruptive, pestilential, or putrid diseases. Hence: Any antidote or panacea.
Having the qualities of an antidote, or of bezoar; healing.
A low fellow or scoundrel; a beggar.
To drink to excess; to revel.
An astringent and narcotic drug made from the dried leaves and seed capsules of wild hemp (Cannabis Indica), and chewed or smoked in the East as a means of intoxication. See Hasheesh.
An Indian monkey (Macacus Rhesus), protected by the Hindoos as sacred. See Rhesus.
In most branches of science bi- in composition denotes two, twice, or doubly; as, bidentate, two-toothed; biternate, doubly ternate, etc.
Having points in two directions.
Having two angles or corners.
Having, or consisting of, tow joints.
A weight on the side of the ball used in the game of bowls, or a tendency imparted to the ball, which turns it from a straight line.
A learning of the mind; propensity or prepossession toward an object or view, not leaving the mind indifferent; bent inclination.
Cut slanting or diagonally, as cloth.
To incline to one side; to give a particular direction to; to influence; to prejudice; to prepossess.
Having two earlike projections at its base, as a leaf.
A small piece of cloth worn by children over the breast, to protect the clothes.
An arctic fish (Gadus luscus), allied to the cod; -- called also pout and whiting pout.
The practice or habit of drinking too much; tippling.
A bibcock. See Bib, n., 3.
One given to drinking alcoholic beverages too freely; a tippler; -- chiefly used in composition; as, winebibber.
A cock or faucet having a bent down nozzle.
Of or pertaining to drinking or tippling.

The Book by way of eminence, -- that is, the book which is made up of the writings accepted by Christians as of divine origin and authority, whether such writings be in the original language, or translated; the Scriptures of the Old and New Testaments; -- sometimes in a restricted sense, the Old Testament; as, King James's Bible; Douay Bible; Luther's Bible. Also, the book which is made up of writings similarly accepted by the Jews; as, a rabbinical Bible.
Pertaining to, or derived from, the Bible; as, biblical learning; biblical authority.
The quality of being biblical; a biblical subject.
According to the Bible.
Learning or literature relating to the Bible.
One skilled in the knowledge of the Bible; a demonstrator of religious truth by the Scriptures.
One who writes, or is versed in, bibliography.
Pertaining to bibliography, or the history of books.
A history or description of books and manuscripts, with notices of the different editions, the times when they were printed, etc.
A worshiper of books; especially, a worshiper of the Bible; a believer in its verbal inspiration.
An account of books; book lore; bibliography.
A mania for acquiring books.
One who has a mania for books.
Pertaining to a passion for books; relating to a bibliomaniac.
Relating to the binding of books.
Pertaining to the art of binding books.
A lover of books.
A lover of books.
A dread of books.
One who sells books.
Of or pertaining to the sale of books.
Of or pertaining to bibliopolism.
Belonging to a library.
One who makes the Bible the sole rule of faith.
Readily imbibing fluids or moisture; spongy; as, bibulous blotting paper.
Inclined to drink; addicted to tippling.
Having two callosities or hard spots.

A carbonate in which but half the hydrogen of the acid is replaced by a positive element or radical, thus making the proportion of the acid to the positive or basic portion twice what it is in the normal carbonates; an acid carbonate; -- sometimes called supercarbonate.
Containing two atoms or equivalents of carbon in the molecule.
Having two keel-like projections, as the upper palea of grasses.
Having, or terminating in, two tails.
Consisting of two hundred years.
Occurring every two hundred years.
A muscle having two heads or origins; -- applied particularly to a flexor in the arm, and to another in the thigh.
A remarkable ganoid fish (Polypterus bichir) found in the Nile and other African rivers. See Brachioganoidei.
A compound consisting of two atoms of chlorine with one or more atoms of another element; -- called also dichloride.
A salt containing two parts of chromic acid to one of the other ingredients; as, potassium bichromate; -- called also dichromate.
To combine or treat with a bichromate, esp. with bichromate of potassium; as, bichromatized gelatine.
Having two heads or origins, as a muscle.
Dividing into two parts at one extremity; having two heads or two supports; as, a bicipital tree.
To contend in petulant altercation; to wrangle.
A fight with stones between two parties of boys.
Having the anterior toes connected by a basal web.
Concave on both sides; as, biconcave vertebr\'91.
Twice paired, as when a petiole forks twice.
Having two horns; two-horned; crescentlike.
Double-bodied, as a lion having one head and two bodies.
Having two principal ribs running longitudinally, as a leaf.
Twice crenated, as in the case of leaves whose crenatures are themselves crenate.
Having the form of a double crescent.
One of the two double-pointed teeth which intervene between the canines (cuspids) and the molars, on each side of each jaw. See Tooth, n.
A light vehicle having two wheels one behind the other. It has a saddle seat and is propelled by the rider's feet acting on cranks or levers.
One who rides a bicycle.
The use of a bicycle; the act or practice of riding a bicycle.
The art of riding a bicycle.
To make an offer of; to propose. Specifically : To offer to pay ( a certain price, as for a thing put up at auction), or to take (a certain price, as for work to be done under a contract).
An offer of a price, especially at auctions; a statement of a sum which one will give for something to be received, or will take for something to be done or furnished; that which is offered.
To make a bid; to state what one will pay or take.
One who bids or offers a price.
Command; order; a proclamation or notifying.
The act or process of making bids; an offer; a proposal of a price, as at an auction.
The prayer before the sermon, with petitions for various specified classes of persons.
To dwell; to inhabit; to abide; to stay.
A small horse formerly allowed to each trooper or dragoon for carrying his baggage.
Happening, or taking place, once in two years; as, a biennial election.
Continuing for two years, and then perishing, as plants which form roots and leaves the first year, and produce fruit the second.
A plant which exists or lasts for two years.
A handbarrow or portable frame on which a corpse is placed or borne to the grave.
A count of forty threads in the warp or chain of woolen cloth.
Twofold; arranged in two rows.
Pointing two ways, as leaves that grow only on opposite sides of a branch; in two vertical rows.
Bearing fruit twice a year.
A sort of apple peculiar to Norfolk, Eng.
A baked apple pressed down into a flat, round cake; a dried apple.
Two-threaded; involving the use of two threads; as, bifilar suspension; a bifilar balance.
Having two long, narrow, whiplike appendages.
Bearing two flowers; two-flowered.
Twofold; double; of two kinds, degrees, etc.
Having two leaflets, as some compound leaves.
An oval sac or cell, found in the leaves of certain plants of the order Arace\'91. It has an opening at each end through which raphides, generated inside, are discharged.
Having two forms, bodies, or shapes.
To divide into two branches.
A forking, or division into two branches.
Great with young; pregnant; swelling; ready to give birth or produce; -- often figuratively.
One who is guilty of bigamy.
The offense of marrying one person when already legally married to another.
Having a great belly; as, a big-bellied man or flagon; advanced in pregnancy.
Having a forked petiole, and a pair of leaflets at the end of each division; biconjugate; twice paired; -- said of a decompound leaf.
Including two tribes or races of men.
A fish of the genus Priacanthus, remarkable for the large size of the eye.
See Big, n. & v.
To make or become big; to enlarge.
, superl. of Big.
A child's cap; a hood, or something worn on the head.
A cap or hood with pieces covering the ears.
A measure of land in India, varying from a third of an acre to an acre.
The Rocky Mountain sheep (Ovis or Caprovis montana).
A corner, bend, or angle; a hollow; as, the bight of a horse's knee; the bight of an elbow.
A bend in a coast forming an open bay; as, the Bight of Benin.
In a tumid, swelling, blustering manner; haughtily; violently.

A large genus of American, mostly tropical, climbing shrubs, having compound leaves and showy somewhat tubular flowers. B. capreolata is the cross vine of the Southern United States. The trumpet creeper was formerly considered to be of this genus.
Of pertaining to, or resembling, the family of plants of which the trumpet flower is an example.
A hypocrite; esp., a superstitious hypocrite.
The state of mind of a bigot; obstinate and unreasoning attachment of one's own belief and opinions, with narrow-minded intolerance of beliefs opposed to them.
The practice or tenets of a bigot.
A compound of two atoms of hydrogen with some other substance.
A trinket; a jewel; -- a word applied to anything small and of elegant workmanship.
Small articles of virtu, as jewelry, trinkets, etc.
Having two pairs, as of leaflets.
A nest of wild bees, wasps, or ants; a swarm.
Having two lips, as the corols of certain flowers.
A two-masted passenger boat or small vessel, used in the bay of Manila.
Formed of two plates, as the stigma of the Mimulus; also, having two elevated ridges, as in the lip of certain flowers.
Formed of, or having, two lamin\'91, or thin plates.
Of or pertaining to the two sides of a central area or organ, or of a central axis; as, bilateral symmetry in animals, where there is a similarity of parts on the right and left sides of the body.
The European whortleberry (Vaccinium myrtillus); also, its edible bluish black fruit.
A long bar or bolt of iron with sliding shackles, and a lock at the end, to confine the feet of prisoners or offenders, esp. on board of ships.
The European water rail.

A yellow, or greenish, viscid fluid, usually alkaline in reaction, secreted by the liver. It passes into the intestines, where it aids in the digestive process. Its characteristic constituents are the bile salts, and coloring matters.
Bitterness of feeling; choler; anger; ill humor; as, to stir one's bile.
That portion of a group of moldings which projects beyond the general surface of a panel; a bolection.
A gallstone, or biliary calculus. See Biliary.
That part of a ship's hull or bottom which is broadest and most nearly flat, and on which she would rest if aground.
To cause to bulge.
Relating or belonging to bile; conveying bile; as, biliary acids; biliary ducts.
A brownish green pigment found in human gallstones and in old bile. It is a derivative of bilirubin.

The berries of two East Indian species of Averrhoa, of the Oxalide\'91 or Sorrel family. They are very acid, and highly esteemed when preserved or pickled. The juice is used as a remedy for skin diseases.
A woman's ornament; habiliment.
A name applied to the amorphous or crystalline mass obtained from bile by the action of alcohol and ether. It is composed of a mixture of the sodium salts of the bile acids.
Of, pertaining to, or included by, two lines; as, bilinear co\'94rdinates.
Containing, or consisting of, two languages; expressed in two languages; as, a bilingual inscription; a bilingual dictionary.
Quality of being bilingual.
One versed in two languages.
Having two tongues, or speaking two languages.
Of or pertaining to the bile.
Disordered in respect to the bile; troubled with and excess of bile; as, a bilious patient; dependent on, or characterized by, an excess of bile; as, bilious symptoms.
A dark green pigment found in small quantity in human gallstones.
A reddish yellow pigment present in human bile, and in that from carnivorous and herbivorous animals; the normal biliary pigment.
Consisting of two letters; as, a biliteral root of a Sanskrit verb.
The property or state of being biliteral.
A green pigment present in the bile, formed from bilirubin by oxidation.
To frustrate or disappoint; to deceive or defraud, by nonfulfillment of engagement; to leave in the lurch; to give the slip to; as, to bilk a creditor.
A cheat; a trick; a hoax.
To join bills, as doves; to caress in fondness.

A weapon of infantry, in the 14th and 15th centuries. A common form of bill consisted of a broad, heavy, double-edged, hook-shaped blade, having a short pike at the back and another at the top, and attached to the end of a long staff.
A declaration made in writing, stating some wrong the complainant has suffered from the defendant, or a fault committed by some person against a law.
To charge or enter in a bill; as, to bill goods.
An English fish, allied to the cod; the coalfish.
A weevil or curculio of various species, as the corn weevil. See Curculio.
A piece of thick plank, armed with iron plates, and fixed on the bow or fore channels of a vessel, for the bill or fluke of the anchor to rest on.
A flat surface, as of a panel or of a fence, on which bills are posted; a bulletin board.
One who negotiates the discount of bills.
Furnished with, or having, a bill, as a bird; -- used in composition; as, broad-billed.
A small paper; a note; a short letter.
A ticket from a public officer directing soldiers at what house to lodge; as, a billet of residence.
A short bar of metal, as of gold or iron.

A name applied to several distinct fishes: (a) The garfish (Tylosurus, or Belone, longirostris) and allied species. (b) The saury, a slender fish of the Atlantic coast (Scomberesox saurus). (c) The Tetrapturus albidus, a large oceanic species related to the swordfish; the spearfish. (d) The American fresh-water garpike (Lepidosteus osseus).
A printed form, used by merchants in making out bills or rendering accounts.
A person who holds a bill or acceptance.
A device by means of which bills, etc., are held.
Of or pertaining to the game of billiards.
A market near the Billings gate in London, celebrated for fish and foul language.
Coarsely abusive, foul, or profane language; vituperation; ribaldry.
One who uses, or is armed with, a bill or hooked ax.
Bullion in the bar or mass.
A great wave or surge of the sea or other water, caused usually by violent wind.
A great wave or flood of anything.
A club; esp., a policeman's club.
A slubbing or roving machine.
Double location; the state or power of being in two places at the same instant; -- a miraculous power attributed to some of the saints.
Lean meat cut into strips and sun-dried.
Animals having two hands; -- a term applied by Cuvier to man as a special order of Mammalia.
Having two hands; two-handed.
Having a double margin, as certain shells.
The condition of having two mamm\'91 or teats.
Applied to a line which is the sum of two lines commensurable only in power (as the side and diagonal of a square).
Having two members; as, a bimembral sentence.
Of or relating to, or using, a double metallic standard (as gold and silver) for a system of coins or currency.
The legalized use of two metals (as gold and silver) in the currency of a country, at a fixed relative value; -- in opposition to monometallism.
Occurring, done, or coming, once in two months; as, bimonthly visits; bimonthly publications.
Once in two months.
Having two adductor muscles, as a bivalve mollusk.
A box, frame, crib, or inclosed place, used as a receptacle for any commodity; as, a corn bin; a wine bin; a coal bin.
To put into a bin; as, to bin wine.
An old form of Be and Been.
A euphonic form of the prefix Bi-.
To tie, or confine with a cord, band, ligature, chain, etc.; to fetter; to make fast; as, to bind grain in bundles; to bind a prisoner.
To confine, restrain, or hold by physical force or influence of any kind; as, attraction binds the planets to the sun; frost binds the earth, or the streams.
To contract; to grow hard or stiff; to cohere or stick together in a mass; as, clay binds by heat.
Any twining or climbing plant or stem, esp. a hop vine; a bine.
Anything that binds, as a fillet, cord, rope, or band; a bandage; -- esp. the principal piece of timber intended to bind together any building.
An amorphous antimonate of lead, produced from the alteration of other ores, as from jamesonite.
Anything that binds; a bandage; the cover of a book, or the cover with the sewing, etc.; something that secures the edge of cloth from raveling.
The condition or property of being binding; obligatory quality.
Two-nerved; -- applied to leaves which have two longitudinal ribs or nerves.
Having only two nerves, as the wings of some insects.
A case or box placed near the helmsman, containing the compass of a ship, and a light to show it at night.
A dioptric telescope, fitted with two tubes joining, so as to enable a person to view an object with both eyes at once; a double-barreled field glass or an opera glass.
Pertaining to both eyes; employing both eyes at once; as, binocular vision.
In a binocular manner.
An expression consisting of two terms connected by the sign plus (+) or minus (-); as, a+b, or 7-3.
Consisting of two terms; pertaining to binomials; as, a binomial root.
Having two names; -- used of the system by which every animal and plant receives two names, the one indicating the genus, the other the species, to which it belongs.
Consisting of two notes; as, a binotonous cry.
A salt having two equivalents of oxalic acid to one of the base; an acid oxalate.
A small Asiatic civet of the genus Arctilis.
Having two nuclei; as, binucleate cells.
Having two ocelli (eyelike spots); -- said of a wing, etc.
The chemistry of living organisms; the chemistry of the processes incidental to, and characteristic of, life.
The doctrine of vital forces or energy.
A doctrine that the genesis or production of living organisms can take place only through the agency of living germs or parents; -- opposed to abiogenesis.
A believer in the theory of biogenesis.
The investigation of life.
One who writes an account or history of the life of a particular person; a writer of lives, as Plutarch.
Of or pertaining to biography; containing biography.
To write a history of the life of.
Biographical writings in general.
A student of biology; one versed in the science of biology.

The science of life; that branch of knowledge which treats of living matter as distinct from matter which is not living; the study of living tissue. It has to do with the origin, structure, development, function, and distribution of animals and plants.
The destruction of life.
Relating to the destruction of life.
Measurement of life; calculation of the probable duration of human life.
The physiological individual, characterized by definiteness and independence of function, in distinction from the morphological individual or morphon.

A name suggested by Dr. Beale for the germinal matter supposed to be essential to the functions of all living beings; the material through which every form of life manifests itself; unaltered protoplasm.
A tiny mass of bioplasm, in itself a living unit and having formative power, as a living white blood corpuscle; bioblast.
A physiological organ; a living organ; an organ endowed with function; -- distinguished from idorgan.
The physical phenomena of organized bodies, in opposition to their organic or vital phenomena.
The classification of living organisms according to their structural character; taxonomy.
Relating to life; as, the biotic principle.
Mica containing iron and magnesia, generally of a black or dark green color; -- a common constituent of crystalline rocks. See Mica.
Palmately branched, with the branches again palmated.
Of or pertaining to the diameter of the cranium, from one parietal fossa to the other.
Bringing forth two at a birth.
Capable of being divided into two parts.
Dividing into two parts.
Divisible into two parts.
Being in two parts; having two correspondent parts, as a legal contract or writing, one for each party; shared by two; as, a bipartite treaty.
Divided into two parts almost to the base, as a leaf; consisting of two parts or subdivisions.
Having two margins toothed like a comb.
A two-footed animal, as man.
Having two feet; two-footed.
Pertaining to a biped.
The larva of certain starfishes as developed in the free-swimming stage.
Relating to books printed at Deuxponts, or Bipontium (Zweibr\'81cken), in Bavaria.
Having two punctures, or spots.
Having an eyelike spot on the wing, with two dots within it of a different color, as in some butterflies.
Consisting of two pyramids placed base to base; having a pyramid at each of the extremities of a prism, as in quartz crystals.
The fourth power, or the square of the square. Thus 4x4=16, the square of 4, and 16x16=256, the biquadrate of 4.
Of or pertaining to the biquadrate, or fourth power.
An aspect of the planets when they are distant from each other by twice the fifth part of a great circle -- that is, twice 72 degrees.
Having two rays; as, a biradiate fin.
Having, or consisting of, two branches.

A tree of several species, constituting the genus Betula; as, the white or common birch (B. alba) (also called silver birch and lady birch); the dwarf birch (B. glandulosa); the paper or canoe birch (B. papyracea); the yellow birch (B. lutea); the black or cherry birch (B. lenta).
The wood or timber of the birch.
To whip with a birch rod or twig; to flog.
Of or relating to birch.
Hence: To seek for game or plunder; to thieve.
A sound made in imitation of the note or cry of a bird for the purpose of decoying the bird or its mate.
An instrument of any kind, as a whistle, used in making the sound of a birdcall.
The art, act, or occupation or catching birds or wild fowls.
A shrub (Prunus Padus ) found in Northern and Central Europe. It bears small black cherries.
Quick-sighted; catching a glance as one goes.
One who takes pleasure in rearing or collecting rare or curious birds.
One who has for sale the various kinds of birds which are kept in cages.

An extremely adhesive viscid substance, usually made of the middle bark of the holly, by boiling, fermenting, and cleansing it. When a twig is smeared with this substance it will hold small birds which may light upon it. Hence: Anything which insnares.
A fowler or birdcatcher.

The name of several very beautiful birds of the genus Paradisea and allied genera, inhabiting New Guinea and the adjacent islands. The males have brilliant colors, elegant plumes, and often remarkable tail feathers.
A molding whose section is thought to resemble a beak.
Canary seed, hemp, millet or other small seeds used for feeding caged birds.
Seen from above, as if by a flying bird; embraced at a glance; hence, generalas, a bird's-eye view.
Marked with spots resembling bird's eyes; as, bird's-eye diaper; bird's-eye maple.
A papilionaceous plant, the Ornithopus, having a curved, cylindrical pod tipped with a short, clawlike point.
The nest in which a bird lays eggs and hatches her young.
The nest of a small swallow (Collocalia nidifica and several allied species), of China and the neighboring countries, which is mixed with soups.
The knotgrass (Polygonum aviculare).
Flighty; passing rapidly from one subject to another; not having the faculty of attention.
An ancient galley or vessel with two banks or tiers of oars.
To whip with a birch or rod.
Birchen; as, birken groves.
Having a double beak, or two processes resembling beaks.
A whirring sound, as of a spinning wheel.
A rush or impetus; force.
A bristle or bristles.
A fish of the turbot kind; the brill.
The act or fact of coming into life, or of being born; -- generally applied to human beings; as, the birth of a son.
Lineage; extraction; descent; sometimes, high birth; noble extraction.
The land of one's birth; one's inheritance.
A genus of herbs and shrubs (Aristolochia), reputed to have medicinal properties.
Twice; -- a word showing that something is, or is to be, repeated; as a passage of music, or an item in accounts.
A form of Bi-, sometimes used before s, c, or a vowel.
Having two little bags, sacs, or pouches.
Of or pertaining to Biscay in Spain.
A confection made of flour, sugar, marmalade, and eggs; a sweet biscuit.
A kind of unraised bread, of many varieties, plain, sweet, or fancy, formed into flat cakes, and bakes hard; as, ship biscuit.
A small loaf or cake of bread, raised and shortened, or made light with soda or baking powder. Usually a number are baked in the same pan, forming a sheet or card.
A cold north wind which prevails on the northern coasts of the Mediterranean and in Switzerland, etc.; -- nearly the same as the mistral.
To cut or divide into two parts.
To divide into two equal parts.
One who, or that which, bisects; esp. (Geom.) a straight line which bisects an angle.
The line bisecting the angle between the optic axes of a biaxial crystal.
One of tow equal parts of a line, or other magnitude.
With two partitions or septa.
Doubly serrate, or having the serratures serrate, as in some leaves.
A spiritual overseer, superintendent, or director.
To make seem younger, by operating on the teeth; as, to bishop an old horse or his teeth.
In the manner of a bishop.
A diocese; the district over which the jurisdiction of a bishop extends.
The office of a spiritual overseer, as of an apostle, bishop, or presbyter.
A canvas for a portrait measuring 58 by 94 inches. The half bishop measures 45 of 56.
A bishop's seat or see.
An umbelliferous plant of the genus Ammi.
Wood betony (Stachys betonica); also, the plant called fennel flower (Nigella Damascena), or devil-in-a-bush.
To busy; to employ.

A salt of metasilicic acid; -- so called because the ratio of the oxygen of the silica to the oxygen of the base is as two to one. The bisilicates include many of the most common and important minerals.
Soup or broth made by boiling several sorts of flesh together.
The fifteen-spined (Gasterosteus spinachia).
Bismuth trioxide, or bismuth ocher.

One of the elements; a metal of a reddish white color, crystallizing in rhombohedrons. It is somewhat harder than lead, and rather brittle; masses show broad cleavage surfaces when broken across. It melts at 507° Fahr., being easily fused in the flame of a candle. It is found in a native state, and as a constituent of some minerals. Specific gravity 9.8. Atomic weight 207.5. Symbol Bi.
Of or pertaining to bismuth; containing bismuth, when this element has its higher valence; as, bismuthic oxide.
Native bismuth sulphide; -- sometimes called bismuthite.
Of, or containing, bismuth, when this element has its lower valence.
Hydrous carbonate of bismuth, an earthy mineral of a dull white or yellowish color.
The aurochs or European bison.
A point taken by the receiver of odds in the game of tennis; also, an extra innings allowed to a weaker player in croquet.
A white soup made of crayfish.

Leap year; every fourth year, in which a day is added to the month of February on account of the excess of the tropical year (365 d. 5 h. 48 m. 46 s.) above 365 days. But one day added every four years is equivalent to six hours each year, which is 11 m. 14 s. more than the excess of the real year. Hence, it is necessary to suppress the bissextile day at the end of every century which is not divisible by 400, while it is retained at the end of those which are divisible by 400.
Pertaining to leap year.
An herbaceous plant of the genus Polygonum, section Bistorta; snakeweed; adderwort. Its root is used in medicine as an astringent.
A surgical instrument consisting of a slender knife, either straight or curved, generally used by introducing it beneath the part to be divided, and cutting towards the surface.
Having two grooves or furrows.
A sulphide having two atoms of sulphur in the molecule; a disulphide, as in iron pyrites, FeS2; -- less frequently called bisulphuret.
A salt of sulphurous acid in which the base replaces but half the hydrogen of the acid; an acid sulphite.
The part of a bridle, usually of iron, which is inserted in the mouth of a horse, and having appendages to which the reins are fastened.
imp. & p. p. of Bite.
A part of anything, such as may be bitten off or taken into the mouth; a morsel; a bite. Hence: A small piece of anything; a little; a mite.
Somewhat; something, but not very great.
A salt of tartaric acid in which the base replaces but half the acid hydrogen; an acid tartrate, as cream of tartar.
The female of the canine kind, as of the dog, wolf, and fox.
An opprobrious name for a woman, especially a lewd woman.
To seize with the teeth, so that they enter or nip the thing seized; to lacerate, crush, or wound with the teeth; as, to bite an apple; to bite a crust; the dog bit a man.
To cause a smarting sensation; to have a property which causes such a sensation; to be pungent; as, it bites like pepper or mustard.
The act of puncturing or abrading with an organ for taking food, as is done by some insects.
One who cheats; a sharper.
That bites; sharp; cutting; sarcastic; caustic.
Not having a bit or bridle.
A stock or handle for holding and rotating a bit; a brace.
To put round the bitts; as, to bitt the cable, in order to fasten it or to slacken it gradually, which is called veering away.
Terminating abruptly, as if bitten off; premorse.
AA turn of the cable which is round the bitts.
Causing pain or smart; piercing; painful; sharp; severe; as, a bitter cold day.
A bitter compound used in adulterating beer; bittern.
In a bitter manner.
A wading bird of the genus Botaurus, allied to the herons, of various species.
A very bitter compound of quassia, cocculus Indicus, etc., used by fraudulent brewers in adulterating beer.

A plant (Lewisia rediviva) allied to the purslane, but with fleshy, farinaceous roots, growing in the mountains of Idaho, Montana, etc. It gives the name to the Bitter Root mountains and river. The Indians call both the plant and the river Sp\'91t'lum.
A liquor, generally spirituous in which a bitter herb, leaf, or root is steeped.
A common name of dolomite; -- so called because it contains magnesia, the soluble salts of which are bitter. See Dolomite.
Sweet and then bitter or bitter and then sweet; esp. sweet with a bitter after taste; hence (Fig.), pleasant but painful.
Anything which is bittersweet.
A kind of apple so called.
The yellow gentian (Gentiana lutea), which has a very bitter taste.
A small bit of anything, of indefinite size or quantity; a short distance.
Having the qualities of bitumen; compounded with bitumen; containing bitumen.
The quality of being bivalent.
Equivalent in combining or displacing power to two atoms of hydrogen; dyad.

A mollusk having a shell consisting of two lateral plates or valves joined together by an elastic ligament at the hinge, which is usually strengthened by prominences called teeth. The shell is closed by the contraction of two transverse muscles attached to the inner surface, as in the clam, -- or by one, as in the oyster. See Mollusca.
A pericarp in which the seed case opens or splits into two parts or valves.
Having two valves, as the oyster and some seed pods; bivalve.
Having two vaults or arches.
A term made up of the two parts <?/ + <?/1 <?/-1, where <?/ and <?/1  are vectors.
(Anat.) Having two bellies or protuberances; as, a biventral, or digastric, muscle, or the biventral lobe of the cerebellum.
Of or relating to the bivium.
Having, or leading, two ways.
The watch of a whole army by night, when in danger of surprise or attack.
To watch at night or be on guard, as a whole army.
Occurring or appearing once every two weeks; fortnightly.
To bewray; to reveal.
Odd in manner or appearance; fantastic; whimsical; extravagant; grotesque.
To utter or tell unnecessarily, or in a thoughtless manner; to publish (secrets or trifles) without reserve or discretion.

Destitute of light, or incapable of reflecting it; of the color of soot or coal; of the darkest or a very dark color, the opposite of white; characterized by such a color; as, black cloth; black hair or eyes.
In a less literal sense: Enveloped or shrouded in darkness; very dark or gloomy; as, a black night; the heavens black with clouds.
That which is destitute of light or whiteness; the darkest color, or rather a destitution of all color; as, a cloth has a good black.
To make black; to blacken; to soil; to sully.
A composition for blacking shoes, boots, etc.; also, one for taking impressions of engraved work.
A ball of black color, esp. one used as a negative in voting; -- in this sense usually two words.
To blacken (leather, shoes, etc.) with blacking.
An edible, fresh-water fish of the United States, of the genus Micropterus. the small-mouthed kind is M. dolomie\'c6; the largemouthed is M. salmoides.
The sea bass. See Blackfish, 3.

In England, a species of thrush (Turdus merula), a singing bird with a fin note; the merle. In America the name is given to several birds, as the Quiscalus versicolor, or crow blackbird; the Agel\'91us ph\'d2niceus, or red-winged blackbird; the cowbird; the rusty grackle, etc. See Redwing.
A broad board painted black, or any black surface on which writing, drawing, or the working of mathematical problems can be done with chalk or crayons. It is much used in schools.
One of several books of a political character, published at different times and for different purposes; -- so called either from the color of the binding, or from the character of the contents.
A small European song bird (Sylvia atricapilla), with a black crown; the mock nightingale.
An apple roasted till black, to be served in a dish of boiled custard.
The male of the European black grouse (Tetrao tetrix, Linn.); -- so called by sportsmen. The female is called gray hen. See Heath grouse.
A pestilence which ravaged Europe and Asia in the fourteenth century.
To make or render black.
A tribe of North American Indians formerly inhabiting the country from the upper Missouri River to the Saskatchewan, but now much reduced in numbers.
A small kind of whale, of the genus Globicephalus, of several species. The most common is G. melas. Also sometimes applied to other whales of larger size.
The tautog of New England (Tautoga).
A friar of the Dominican order; -- called also predicant and preaching friar; in France, Jacobin. Also, sometimes, a Benedictine.

The scullions and lower menials of a court, or of a nobleman's household, who, in a removal from one residence to another, had charge of the kitchen utensils, and being smutted by them, were jocularly called the "black guard"; also, the servants and hangers-on of an army.
The criminals and vagrants or vagabonds of a town or community, collectively.
The conduct or language of a blackguard; rufflanism.
In the manner of or resembling a blackguard; abusive; scurrilous; ruffianly.
A heart-shaped cherry with a very dark-colored skin.
Having a wicked, malignant disposition; morally bad.

A dungeon or dark cell in a prison; a military lock-up or guardroom; -- now commonly with allusion to the cell (the Black Hole) in a fort at Calcutta, into which 146 English prisoners were thrust by the nabob Suraja Dowla on the night of June 20, 17656, and in which 123 of the prisoners died before morning from lack of air.
The act or process of making black.
A name given by English miners to sphalerite, or zinc blende; -- called also false galena. See Blende.
Caramel or burnt sugar, used to color wines, spirits, ground coffee, etc.
To coat or to polish with black lead.
A disease among calves and sheep, characterized by a settling of gelatinous matter in the legs, and sometimes in the neck.
Written or printed in black letter; as, a black-letter manuscript or book.
Given to the study of books in black letter; that is, of old books; out of date.
Payment of money exacted by means of intimidation; also, extortion of money from a person by threats of public accusation, exposure, or censure.
One who extorts, or endeavors to extort, money, by black mailing.
The act or practice of extorting money by exciting fears of injury other than bodily harm, as injury to reputation.
Easter Monday, so called from the severity of that day in 1360, which was so unusual that many of Edward III.'s soldiers, then before Paris, died from the cold.
Using foul or scurrilous language; slanderous.
The quality or state of being black; black color; atrociousness or enormity in wickedness.
A kind of sausage made of blood, suet, etc., thickened with meal.
The name of a kind of in used in copperplate printing, prepared from the charred husks of the grape, and residue of the wine press.
Soot flying in the air.
A fish of the Pacific coast (Chromis, or Heliastes, punctipinnis), of a blackish color.
Bad port wine; any commo wine of the Mediterranean; -- so called by sailors.
The black-tailed deer (Cervus or Cariacus Columbianus) of California and Oregon; also, the mule deer of the Rocky Mountains. See Mule deer.
A copious vomiting of dark-colored matter; or the substance so discharged; -- one of the most fatal symptoms in yellow fever.
A lotion made by mixing calomel and lime water.
A wash that blackens, as opposed to whitewash; hence, figuratively, calumny.

A bag or sac in animals, which serves as the receptacle of some fluid; as, the urinary bladder; the gall bladder; -- applied especially to the urinary bladder, either within the animal, or when taken out and inflated with air.
To put up in bladders; as, bladdered lard.
Having bladders; also, resembling a bladder.
Properly, the leaf, or flat part of the leaf, of any plant, especially of gramineous plants. The term is sometimes applied to the spire of grasses.
To put forth or have a blade.
Having a blade or blades; as a two-bladed knife.
Divested of blades; as, bladed corn.
Mendacious boasting; falcefood; humbug.
An inflammatory swelling or sore; a bulla, pustule, or blister.
A bladder growing on the root of the tongue of a horse, against the windpipe, and stopping the breath.
To censure; to express disapprobation of; to find fault with; to reproach.
That which is deserving of censure or disapprobation; culpability; fault; crime; sin.
Attributing blame or fault; implying or conveying censure; faultfinding; censorious.
The quality or state of being blameless; innocence.
A kind of linen cloth made in Normandy, the thread of which is partly blanches before it is woven.
To take the color out of, and make white; to bleach; as, to blanch linen; age has blanched his hair.
One who, or that which, blanches or whitens; esp., one who anneals and cleanses money; also, a chemical preparation for this purpose.
One who, or that which, frightens away or turns aside.
An instrument for measuring the bleaching power of chloride of lime and potash; a chlorometer.
A sort of fricassee with white sauce, variously made of capon, fish, etc.
Mild; soft; gentle; smooth and soothing in manner; suave; as, a bland temper; bland persuasion; a bland sycophant.
To blandish any one.
To make agreeable and enticing.
The act of blandishing; a word or act expressive of affection or kindness, and tending to win the heart; soft words and artful caresses; cajolery; allurement.
The state or quality of being bland.
Of a white or pale color; without color.
To blanch; to make blank; to damp the spirits of; to dispirit or confuse.
A piece of rubber, felt, or woolen cloth, used in the tympan to make it soft and elastic.
To toss in a blanket by way of punishment.
The act or punishment of tossing in a blanket.
Directly; flatly; point blank.
A large fish of Florida and the W. Indies (Caulolatilus chrysops). It is red, marked with yellow.
To sound loudly and somewhat harshly.

An indignity offered to God in words, writing, or signs; impiously irreverent words or signs addressed to, or used in reference to, God; speaking evil of God; also, the act of claiming the attributes or prerogatives of deity.
Figuratively, of things held in high honor: Calumny; abuse; vilification.

Hence, to affect with some sudden violence, plague, calamity, or blighting influence, which destroys or causes to fail; to visit with a curse; to curse; to ruin; as, to blast pride, hopes, or character.
To blow; to blow on a trumpet.
Relating to the blastema; rudimentary.
Connected with, or proceeding from, the blastema; blastemal.
One who, or that which, blasts or destroys.
A small, clear space in the segments of the ovum, the precursor of the nucleus.
A blast; destruction by a blast, or by some pernicious cause.
The act or process of one who, or that which, blasts; the business of one who blasts.
The germinal membrane in an ovum, from which the embryo is developed.
Of or pertaining to the blastoderm.
Multiplication or increase by gemmation or budding.
One of the Blastoidea.
One of the divisions of Crinoidea found fossil in paleozoic rocks; pentremites. They are so named on account of their budlike form.
One of the segments first formed by the division of the ovum.
That portion of the spermatospore which is not converted into spermatoblasts, but carries them.
The pore or opening leading into the cavity of invagination, or archenteron.
In certain hydroids, an imperfect zooid, whose special function is to produce medusoid buds. See Hydroidea, and Athecata.
The exhaust pipe of a steam engine, or any pipe delivering steam or air, when so constructed as to cause a blast.
That stage in the development of the ovum in which the outer cells of the morula become more defined and form the blastoderm.
Affected by blasts; gusty.
Causing blast or injury.
Bellowing, as a calf; bawling; brawling; clamoring; disagreeably clamorous; sounding loudly and harshly.
A blustering, talkative fellow.
One who blatters; a babbler; a noisy, blustering boaster.
Senseless babble or boasting.
A senseless babbler or boaster.
A fish. See Bleak, n.
A stream of gas or vapor emitting light and heat in the process of combustion; a bright flame.
Intense, direct light accompanied with heat; as, to seek shelter from the blaze of the sun.
To send forth or reflect glowing or brilliant light; to show a blaze.
To designate by blazing; to mark out, as by blazed trees; as, to blaze a line or path.
An heraldic shield; a coat of arms, or a bearing on a coat of arms; armorial bearings.
One who gives publicity, proclaims, or blazons; esp., one who blazons coats of arms; a herald.
Same as Blazon, 3.
A coat of arms; an armorial bearing or bearings.
To make white, or whiter; to remove the color, or stains, from; to blanch; to whiten.
A place or an establishment where bleaching is done.
The act or process of whitening, by removing color or stains; esp. the process of whitening fabrics by chemical agents.
Desolate and exposed; swept by cold winds.
Causing or caused by dimness of sight; dim.
Lacking in perception or penetration; short-sighted; as, a blear-eyed bigot.
To make the noise of, or one like that of, a sheep; to cry like a sheep or calf.
To blacken; also, to defile.
Complexion; color; hue; likeness; form.
To withdraw blood from the body; to let blood; as, Dr. A. bleeds in fevers.
To lose, as blood; to emit or let drop, as sap.
A running or issuing of blood, as from the nose or a wound; a hemorrhage; the operation of letting blood, as in surgery; a drawing or running of sap from a tree or plant.
To mark with deformity; to injure or impair, as anything which is well formed, or excellent; to mar, or make defective, either the body or mind.
To tarnish, as reputation or character; to defame.
To draw back from; to deny from fear.
One who blenches, flinches, or shrinks back.
To mix or mingle together; esp. to mingle, combine, or associate so that the separate things mixed, or the line of demarcation, can not be distinguished. Hence: To confuse; to confound.
To pollute by mixture or association; to spoil or corrupt; to blot; to stain.
To make blind, literally or figuratively; to dazzle; to deceive.
One who, or that which, blends; an instrument, as a brush, used in blending.
The act of mingling.
The method of laying on different tints so that they may mingle together while wet, and shade into each other insensibly.
A distemper incident to cattle, in which their livers are affected.
To blink; to shine; to look.
Of, pertaining to, or resembling, the blennies.
An inordinate secretion and discharge of mucus.
Mingled; mixed; blended; also, polluted; stained.
A South African antelope (Alcelaphus albifrons), having a large white spot on the forehead.
To make or pronounce holy; to consecrate
To make happy, blithesome, or joyous; to confer prosperity or happiness upon; to grant divine favor to.
One who blesses; one who bestows or invokes a blessing.
The act of one who blesses.
A declaration of divine favor, or an invocation imploring divine favor on some or something; a benediction; a wish of happiness pronounces.
The supposed faculty of perceiving subterraneous springs and currents by sensation; -- so called from one Bleton, of France.
A form of decay seen in fleshy, overripe fruit.
An inflammation in the foot of a horse, between the sole and the bone.
Hence: To destroy the happiness of; to ruin; to mar essentially; to frustrate; as, to blight one's prospects.

Mildew; decay; anything nipping or blasting; -- applied as a general name to various injuries or diseases of plants, causing the whole or a part to wither, whether occasioned by insects, fungi, or atmospheric influences.
The act of blighting, or the state of being blighted; a withering or mildewing, or a stoppage of growth in the whole or a part of a plant, etc.
So as to cause blight.
To stop; to cease; to desist.
Destitute of the sense of seeing, either by natural defect or by deprivation; without sight.
Something to mislead the eye or the understanding, or to conceal some covert deed or design; a subterfuge.
A cover or protection for an advanced trench or approach, formed of fascines and earth supported by a framework.
One who, or that which, blinds.
One of the leather screens on a bridle, to hinder a horse from seeing objects at the side; a blinker.
To cover the eyes of, as with a bandage; to hinder from seeing.
A thin coating of sand and fine gravel over a newly paved road. See Blind, v. t., 4.
Without sight, discernment, or understanding; without thought, investigation, knowledge, or purpose of one's own.
State or condition of being blind, literally or figuratively.
A small, burrowing, snakelike, limbless lizard (Anguis fragilis), with minute eyes, popularly believed to be blind; the slowworm; -- formerly a name for the adder.
To wink; to twinkle with, or as with, the eye.
To trick; to deceive.
That which twinkles or glances, as a dim star, which appears and disappears.
A blinder for horses; a flap of leather on a horse's bridle to prevent him from seeing objects as his side hence, whatever obstructs sight or discernment.
Lascivious; also, in heat; -- said of ewes.

A vesicle of the skin, containing watery matter or serum, whether occasioned by a burn or other injury, or by a vesicatory; a collection of serous fluid causing a bladderlike elevation of the cuticle.
Any elevation made by the separation of the film or skin, as on plants; or by the swelling of the substance at the surface, as on steel.
To give pain to, or to injure, as if by a blister.
In a blithe manner.
The state of being blithe.
To make turgid, as with water or air; to cause a swelling of the surface of, from effusion of serum in the cellular tissue, producing a morbid enlargement, often accompanied with softness.
To inflate; to puff up; to make vain.
To dry (herrings) in smoke. See Blote.
Distended beyond the natural or usual size, as by the presence of water, serum, etc.; turgid; swollen; as, a bloated face. Also, puffed up with pride; pompous.
The state of being bloated.
The common herring, esp. when of large size, smoked, and half dried; -- called also bloat herring.
Something blunt and round; a small drop or lump of something viscid or thick; a drop; a bubble; a blister.
A small fresh-water fish (Uranidea Richardsoni); the miller's thumb.

A piece of wood more or less bulky; a solid mass of wood, stone, etc., usually with one or more plane, or approximately plane, faces; as, a block on which a butcher chops his meat; a block by which to mount a horse; children's playing blocks, etc.
Hence, to shut in so as to prevent egress.
A vessel employed in blockading.
A book printed from engraved wooden blocks instead of movable types.
A stupid fellow; a dolt; a person deficient in understanding.
That which characterizes a blockhead; stupidity.
A house of squared logs.
Blocks used to support (a building, etc.) temporarily.
Like a block; deficient in understanding; stupid; dull.
Like a block; stupid.
A hydrous sulphate of magnesium and sodium.
A person of very fair complexion, with light hair and light blue eyes.
A kind of silk lace originally of the color of raw silk, now sometimes dyed; -- called also blond lace.
The state of being blond.
Relationship by descent from a common ancestor; consanguinity; kinship.
Having the hair matted with clotted blood.
Guilty of murder or bloodshed.

A breed of large and powerful dogs, with long, smooth, and pendulous ears, and remarkable for acuteness of smell. It is employed to recover game or prey which has escaped wounded from a hunter, and for tracking criminals. Formerly it was used for pursuing runaway slaves. Other varieties of dog are often used for the same purpose and go by the same name. The Cuban bloodhound is said to be a variety of the mastiff.
In a bloody manner; cruelly; with a disposition to shed blood.
The state of being bloody.
Disposition to shed blood; bloodthirstiness.
Not attended with shedding of blood, or slaughter; as, a bloodless victory.
The act or process of letting blood or bleeding, as by opening a vein or artery, or by cupping or leeches; -- esp. applied to venesection.
Money paid to the next of kin of a person who has been killed by another.

Money obtained as the price, or at the cost, of another's life; -- said of a reward for supporting a capital charge, of money obtained for betraying a fugitive or for committing murder, or of money obtained from the sale of that which will destroy the purchaser.
One who sheds blood; a manslayer; a murderer.
A piece of hard wood loaded at one end with lead, and used to strike the fleam into the vein.
Loss of sensation and motion from hemorrhage or congestion in the brain.
One who sheds blood; a cruel, bloodthirsty man; one guilty of bloodshed; a murderer.
Any vessel or canal in which blood circulates in an animal, as an artery or vein.
A fine or amercement paid as a composition for the shedding of blood; also, a riot wherein blood was spilled.
A tree having the wood or the sap of the color of blood.
Containing or resembling blood; of the nature of blood; as, bloody excretions; bloody sweat.
Smeared or stained with blood; as, bloody hands; a bloody handkerchief.
The dysentery, a disease in which the flux or discharge from the bowels has a mixture of blood.
A red hand, as in the arms of Ulster, which is now the distinguishing mark of a baronet of the United Kingdom.
A blossom; the flower of a plant; an expanded bud; flowers, collectively.
The opening of flowers in general; the state of blossoming or of having the flowers open; as, the cherry trees are in bloom.
To bestow a bloom upon; to make blooming or radiant.
A costume for women, consisting of a short dress, with loose trousers gathered round ankles, and (commonly) a broad-brimmed hat.
A woman who wears a Bloomer costume.
The process of making blooms from the ore or from cast iron.
Opening in blossoms; flowering.
Thriving in health, beauty, and vigor; indicating the freshness and beauties of youth or health.
Without bloom or flowers.
Covered with bloom, as fruit.
Full of blossoms; flowery.
To spot, stain, or bespatter, as with ink.
A spot or stain, as of ink on paper; a blur.
An obliteration of something written or printed; an erasure.
A weak point; a failing; an exposed point or mark.
A large pustule, or a coarse eruption.
To cure, as herrings, by salting and smoking them; to bloat.
One who, or that which blots; esp. a device for absorbing superfluous ink.
A light, loose over-garment, like a smock frock, worn especially by workingmen in France; also, a loose coat of any material, as the undress uniform coat of the United States army.
To flower; to blossom; to bloom.
A sudden or forcible act or effort; an assault.
To send forth a forcible current of air, as from the mouth or from a pair of bellows.
To drive by a current air; to impel; as, the tempest blew the ship ashore.
The act of forcing air from the mouth, or through or from some instrument; as, to give a hard blow on a whistle or horn; to give the fire a blow with the bellows.

A device for producing a current of air; as: (a) A metal plate temporarily placed before the upper part of a grate or open fire. (b) A machine for producing an artificial blast or current of air by pressure, as for increasing the draft of a furnace, ventilating a building or shaft, cleansing gram, etc.

A tube, as of cane or reed, sometimes twelve feet long, through which an arrow or other projectile may be impelled by the force of the breath. It is a weapon much used by certain Indians of America and the West Indies; -- called also blowpipe, and blowtube.  See Sumpitan.
A cavern in a cliff, at the water level, opening to the air at its farther extremity, so that the waters rush in with each surge and rise in a lofty jet from the extremity.
A nostril or spiracle in the top of the head of a whale or other cetacean.
An outburst of temper or excitement.
A tube for directing a jet of air into a fire or into the flame of a lamp or candle, so as to concentrate the heat on some object.
A blowgun; a blowtube.
A blossoming; a bloom.
A similar instrument, commonly of tin, used by boys for discharging paper wads and other light missiles.
Windy; as, blowy weather; a blowy upland.
A ruddy, fat-faced woman; a wench.
To swell; to puff out, as with weeping.
To give vent to (tears) or utter (broken words or cries); -- with forth or out.
Like blubber; gelatinous and quivering; as, a blubbery mass.
Having the color of the clear sky, or a hue resembling it, whether lighter or darker; as, the deep, blue sea; as blue as a sapphire; blue violets.
Pale, without redness or glare, -- said of a flame; hence, of the color of burning brimstone, betokening the presence of ghosts or devils; as, the candle burns blue; the air was blue with oaths.
A pedantic woman; a bluestocking.
A trout (Salmo oquassa) inhabiting some of the lakes of Maine.

The hero of a medi\'91val French nursery legend, who, leaving home, enjoined his young wife not to open a certain room in his castle. She entered it, and found the murdered bodies of his former wives. -- Also used adjectively of a subject which it is forbidden to investigate.

The berry of several species of Vaccinium, and ericaceous genus, differing from the American huckleberries in containing numerous minute seeds instead of ten nutlets. The commonest species are V. Pennsylvanicum and V. vacillans.  V. corymbosum is the tall blueberry.
A duck of the genus Fuligula. Two American species (F. marila and F. affinis) are common. See Scaup duck.

A small song bird (Sialia sialis), very common in the United States, and, in the north, one of the earliest to arrive in spring. The male is blue, with the breast reddish. It is related to the European robin.
A plant. Same as Bluebottle.
The United States official "Biennial Register."
A large and troublesome species of blowfly (Musca vomitoria). Its body is steel blue.
A Scot; a Scotchman; -- so named from wearing a blue bonnet.
The blue-cheeked honeysucker of Australia.
a grasslike plant (Sisyrinchium anceps), with small flowers of a delicate blue color.
A species of whitefish (Coregonus nigripinnis) found in Lake Michigan.

A large voracious fish (Pomatomus saitatrix), of the family Carangid\'91, valued as a food fish, and widely distributed on the American coast. On the New Jersey and Rhode Island coast it is called the horse mackerel, in Virginia saltwater tailor, or skipjack.
A West Indian fish (Platyglossus radiatus), of the family Labrid\'91.
A species of grass (Poa compressa) with bluish green stems, valuable in thin gravelly soils; wire grass.
A name given to fluor spar in Derbyshire, where it is used for ornamental purposes.
With a blue color.
A kind of salmon (Salmo Cambricus) found in Wales.
A literary lady; a female pedant.
The American avocet (Recurvirostra Americana).
A grayish blue building stone, as that commonly used in the eastern United States.
A name given to several different species of plants having blue flowers, as the Houstonia c\'d2rulea, the Centaurea cyanus or bluebottle, and the Vaccinium angustifolium.
Having blue veins or blue streaks.
The blue-winged teal. See Teal.
Rising steeply with a flat or rounded front.
An act of bluffing; an expression of self-confidence for the purpose of intimidation; braggadocio; as, that is only bluff, or a bluff.
To frighten or deter from accomplishing a purpose by making a show of confidence in one's strength or resources; as, he bluffed me off.
Built with the stem nearly straight up and down.
Built with the stem nearly straight up and down.
The quality or state of being bluff.
Having bluffs, or bold, steep banks.
Inclined to bo bluff; brusque.
Something to give a bluish tint, as indigo, or preparations used by washerwomen.
To make a gross error or mistake; as, to blunder in writing or preparing a medical prescription.
To move in an awkward, clumsy manner; to flounder and stumble.
To do or treat in a blundering manner; to confuse.
A gross error or mistake, resulting from carelessness, stupidity, or culpable ignorance.
A stupid, blundering fellow.
A stupid, blundering fellow.
In a blundering manner.
To amalgamate and blend; to beat up or mix in water, as clay.
A wooden blade with a cross handle, used for mi<?/ing the clay in potteries; a plunger.
Dull in understanding; slow of discernment; stupid; -- opposed to acute.
To repress or weaken, as any appetite, desire, or power of the mind; to impair the force, keenness, or susceptibility, of; as, to blunt the feelings.
A short needle with a strong point. See Needle.
In a blunt manner; coarsely; plainly; abruptly; without delicacy, or the usual forms of civility.
A bruptness of address; rude plainness.
A dim, confused appearance; indistinctness of vision; as, to see things with a blur; it was all blur.
To utter suddenly and unadvisedly; to divulge inconsiderately; to ejaculate; -- commonly with out.
To become suffused with red in the cheeks, as from a sense of shame, modesty, or confusion; to become red from such cause, as the cheeks or face.
To express or make known by blushing.
A red or reddish color; a rosy tint.
In a blushing manner; with a blush or blushes; as, to answer or confess blushingly.
Free from blushes; incapable of blushing; shameless; impudent.
To blow fitfully with violence and noise, as wind; to be windy and boisterous, as the weather.
Exhibiting noisy violence, as the wind; stormy; tumultuous.
Uttering noisy threats; noisy and swaggering; boisterous.
Inclined to bluster; given to blustering; blustering.
A genus of large American serpents, including the boa constrictor, the emperor boa of Mexico (B. imperator), and the chevalier boa of Peru (B. eques).
A long, round fur tippet; -- so called from its resemblance in shape to the boa constrictor.
The uncastrated male of swine; specifically, the wild hog.
A piece of timber sawed thin, and of considerable length and breadth as compared with the thickness, -- used for building, etc.
A table to put food upon.
To go on board of, or enter, as a ship, whether in a hostile or a friendly way.
One who has food statedly at another's table, or meals and lodgings in his house, for pay, or compensation of any kind.
One who boards a ship; one selected to board an enemy's ship.
The act of covering with boards; also, boards, collectively; or a covering made of boards.
To speak in exulting language of another; to glory; to exult.
To shape roughly as a preparation for the finer work to follow; to cut to the general form required.
A stone mason's broad-faced chisel.
Given to, or full of, boasting; inclined to boast; vaunting; vainglorious; self-praising.
The act of glorying or vaunting; vainglorious speaking; ostentatious display.
Without boasting or ostentation.
A small open vessel, or water craft, usually moved by cars or paddles, but often by a sail.
To place in a boat; as, to boat oars.
Navigable for boats, or small river craft.
A wading bird (Cancroma cochlearia) of the tropical parts of South America. Its bill is somewhat like a boat with the keel uppermost.
A perching bird of India, of the genus Eurylaimus.
The quantity or amount that fills a boat.
A house for sheltering boats.
In Persia, a punishment of capital offenders, by laying them on the back in a covered boat, where they are left to perish.
A boat bug. See Boat bug.
A marine gastropod of the genus Crepidula. The species are numerous. It is so named from its form and interior deck.
An officer who has charge of the boats, sails, rigging, colors, anchors, cables, cordage, etc., of a ship, and who also summons the crew, and performs other duties.
A woman who manages a boat.
Anything that hangs so as to play loosely, or with a short abrupt motion, as at the end of a string; a pendant; as, the bob at the end of a kite's tail.
A knot of worms, or of rags, on a string, used in angling, as for eels; formerly, a worm suitable for bait.
To strike with a quick, light blow; to tap.
To angle with a bob. See Bob, n., 2 & 3.
A squabble; a tumult; a noisy disturbance; as, to raise a bobbery.

A spool or reel of various material and construction, with a head at one or both ends, and sometimes with a hole bored through its length by which it may be placed on a spindle or pivot. It is used to hold yarn or thread, as in spinning or warping machines, looms, sewing machines, etc.
Hearty; in good spirits.
The fly at the end of the leader; an end fly.
An American singing bird (Dolichonyx oryzivorus). The male is black and white; the female is brown; -- called also, ricebird, reedbird, and Boblincoln.
An animal (as a horse or dog) with a short tail.
The common qua(Colinus, or Ortyx, Virginianus); -- so called from its note.
A short wig with bobs or short curls; -- called also bobtail wig.
A form of syllogism of which the first and third propositions are particular negatives, and the middle term a universal affirmative.
A prison; -- originally the name of the old north gate in Oxford, which was used as a prison.
The round hole in the furnace of a glass manufactory through which the fused glass is taken out.
A strong beer, originally made in Bavaria.
A kind of long-winged hawk; -- called also bockerel, and bockeret.
A bowl or vessel made from a gourd.
To indicate by signs, as future events; to be the omen of; to portend to presage; to foreshow.
A bid; an offer.
A large food fish (Diagramma lineatum), native of the East Indies.
A kind of under waist stiffened with whalebone, etc., worn esp. by women; a corset; stays.
A close-fitting outer waist or vest forming the upper part of a woman's dress, or a portion of it.
Without material form; incorporeal.
Of or pertaining to the body, in distinction from the mind.
A prognostic; an omen; a foreboding.
The material organized substance of an animal, whether living or dead, as distinguished from the spirit, or vital principle; the physical person.
A colonist or farmer in South Africa of Dutch descent.
A quagmire filled with decayed moss and other vegetable matter; wet spongy ground where a heavy body is apt to sink; a marsh; a morass.
A goblin; a bugbear. See Bogy.
To stop or hesitate as if suddenly frightened, or in doubt, or impeded by unforeseen difficulties; to take alarm; to exhibit hesitancy and indecision.
Consisting of, or containing, a bog or bogs; of the nature of a bog; swampy; as, boggy land.
A four-wheeled truck, having a certain amount of play around a vertical axis, used to support in part a locomotive on a railway track.
A goblin; a specter; a frightful phantom; a bogy; a bugbear.
The American woodcock; -- so called from its feeding among the bogs.
One who lives in a boggy country; -- applied in derision to the lowest class of Irish.
To fall off from the wind; to edge away to leeward; -- said only of inferior craft.
The boce; -- called also bogue bream. See Boce.
Spurious; fictitious; sham; -- a cant term originally applied to counterfeit coin, and hence denoting anything counterfeit.
A liquor made of rum and molasses.
A specter; a hobgoblin; a bugbear.
Fig.: The region or community of social Bohemians. See Bohemian, n., 3.
Of or pertaining to a social gypsy or "Bohemian" (see Bohemian, n., 3); vagabond; unconventional; free and easy.
The language of the Czechs (the ancient inhabitants of Bohemia), the richest and most developed of the dialects of the Slavic family.

To be agitated, or tumultuously moved, as a liquid by the generation and rising of bubbles of steam (or vapor), or of currents produced by heating it to the boiling point; to be in a state of ebullition; as, the water boils.
To be agitated like boiling water, by any other cause than heat; to bubble; to effervesce; as, the boiling waves.
To form, or separate, by boiling or evaporation; as, to boil sugar or salt.
A hard, painful, inflamed tumor, which, on suppuration, discharges pus, mixed with blood, and discloses a small fibrous mass of dead tissue, called the core.
Dressed or cooked by boiling; subjected to the action of a boiling liquid; as, boiled meat; a boiled dinner; boiled clothes.
A vessel in which any thing is boiled.
Heated to the point of bubbling; heaving with bubbles; in tumultuous agitation, as boiling liquid; surging; seething; swelling with heat, ardor, or passion.
Exposure to the action of a hot liquid.
Rough or rude; unbending; unyielding; strong; powerful.
Exhibiting tumultuous violence and fury; acting with noisy turbulence; violent; rough; stormy.
